PN001.message: Use American spelling, not British spelling

PN003.message: Avoid diacritics such as accents, umlauts etc.

PN004.message: Avoid pluralization for names based on domain and repeat content

PN007.message: Avoid using an abbreviation as the complete name

PN008.message: An abbreviation may be part of a protein name

PN009.message: Protein name based on a protein symbol (PS) or gene symbol (GS): Prokaryote symbol guidelines

PN010.message: Protein name based on a protein symbol (PS) or gene symbol (GS): Eukaryote symbol guidelines

PN011.good example: H(+)-transporting V0 sector ATPase subunit c'

PN012.message: Chemical symbols may be part of a protein name

PN013.message: Standard scientific abbreviations may be part of a protein name

PN014.message: Do not use a back slash: ‘\’.

PN015.message: For separating multiple domains or functions, the forward slash ‘/’ or the word ‘and’ may be used.
PN015.good example: WD repeat and FYVE domain-containing protein 3

PN016.message: Compound adjective: a hyphen should be used to form compound modifiers (i.e. two or more words that are acting as a single modifier for a noun)

PN018.message: Avoid use of commas except when their usage is part of accepted chemical names.
PN018.bad example: Phycobilisome 27.9 kDa linker polypeptide, phycoerythrin-associated, rod

PN019.message: Avoid the semi-colon ";" or colon “:” except when it is part of an enzyme name.

PN022.good example: guanine nucleotide-binding protein G(t) subunit alpha-3

PN023.message: Data submitters should not let Microsoft Excel, Word, Outlook, or any other utility with format interpolation and spelling autocorrection touch any protein names, especially those with quotes and double-hyphens.

PN024.message: Use Arabic rather than Roman numerals

PN025.message: Specifying different members encoded by a multigene family

PN027.message: Greek letters should be written in full and entirely in lower case when indicating one of a series of proteins e.g. "alpha", "beta", “gamma”.

PN028.message: In the context of steroid/fatty acid metabolism nomenclature, “Delta” should start with an upper case letter.

PN029.message: Usage of the term 'protein' in a name

PN030.message: Usage of the term ‘enzyme’ in a name

PN033.message: Use this format: --tRNA (tRNA type using the three-letter amino acid code with the first letter capitalized) ligase

PN035.message: Avoid kingdom, genus or species-specific characteristics in a name

PN036.bad example: histidine kinase sensor of two component system

PN039.message: Established and maintained database authorities such as species-specific nomenclature bodies (some are listed here: http://www.uniprot.org/docs/nomlist).

PN040.message: Avoid names from species-specific authorities that relate to phenotype, anatomical features or any taxon-specific characteristics. In these cases, use the widely recognized gene symbol in combination with a functional name rather than a phenotypical name. For example, ‘minichromosome maintenance complex component 7’ is not applicable to organisms which do not have minichromosomes so to avoid transferring such a protein name, use the gene symbol MCM7 combined with a functional name instead.

PN041.message: a) Expert sources of specific and definitive names may include: Enzyme names from Enzyme Commission (EC)

PN042.message: Expert sources of specific and definitive names may include: NCBIfam

PN043.message: a) Expert sources of specific and definitive names may include: UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot

PN044.message: Individual scientists who specialize in a protein family.

PN045.message: A recent literature-supported name from a paper that characterized the protein function is likely the most specific and definitive name to apply (with format refinement as needed). The literature may provide a history of names over time.

PN046.message: Expert sources of specific and definitive names may include: TIGRFam

PN047.message: Expert sources of specific and definitive names may include: Pfam

PN048.message: If no other name is applicable, the words bifunctional or multifunctional may be used in combination with the functional names.

PN049.message: Use 'subunit', not 'chain' or 'component', for members of protein complexes. The exception is historical cases where ‘chain’ is exclusively used e.g. myosins, clathrins, dyneins.
PN049.bad example: Sarcosine reductase complex component B alpha chain

PN050.message: Inactive proteins do not refer to pseudogenes. Inactive versions of proteins refer to proteins with altered catalytic residues or inability to undergo autocatalytic cleavage, resulting in loss of expected activity. Reserve the usage of “inactive” in a protein name for such cases.

PN051.message: use the default name ‘hypothetical protein’ or ‘uncharacterized protein’ (all lowercase) with no further specifications.
